- provides good benefits (insurance, retirement fund, T-pass discounts, employee discounts in various vendors, occasional bonuses)
- generally friendly employees and supervisors

review_title: Toxic work culture. No merit-based pay raise
pros: You will get a chance to learn a lot in only a few months since they give you hands-on opportunities and throw you out there (even when you're not ready yet - not sure if it's a pros or cons), but you definitely learn much quicker this way. However, once the learning phase passes, everything is repetitive.
cons:
Management does not care about personal development at all. They want you to obey orders and be in that same position for the rest of your career. Never ever fall for their compliments when you excel at your work. It's meaningless. It will never translate to a raise or a promotion or anything more tangible than just words. They will always favor the person who sucks up to them the most, even when those people do not have any accomplishments to back it up. Coworkers talk behind each other's back all the time. Employees here have all worked here for 10, 15 years and they're stuck in their never-changing day-to-day tasks that they would complain about every single, no matter how minor, things, and don't even make an effort to try to fix any problems. If you're a person who's ambitious, do not work here. I've seen people with amazing dreams gradually deteriorates into these excessive whiners that will take no actions to make things better. If you want a stable job with the same weekly paycheck + constant 2% annual raise (lower than inflation rate) for your next 20 years, please do so and join BWH.

Expect people to give up their lunches every day. Try to guilt-trip you because the sick patients are waiting.

Racial micro-aggression from both patients and coworkers and upper management. It might seem diverse, but POC are mostly in supporting roles while the decision-making roles are mostly white. If you're one of the few, expect the subtle jabs here and there with skepticism on your qualifications.

pros: loved the work, good pay, many great employees
cons: Management non responsive, hard to make any productive change, understaffed, some unsafe staffing,

Certain departments are very good at rewarding bad behavior. I worked under people who should have never been promoted to supervisor roles. review_title: Bad "leaders" are running that ship to a berg
pros: Has the structure, opportunity and potential to be a great employer and impactful community hospital system. Also, there are some amazing people working there with hearts of gold at all levels. The higher you go though, the shadier they get generally.
cons:
Unfortunately their focus is money and greed over patients and their own staff, wish there was a nicer way to say it and I wish this was not my view.
 
They have an office of strategic communication, lawyers, branding team, HR and overcompensated executive leadership team who are the ultimate pros at white washing, glorifying and virtue signaling everything they do, including themselves; it's kind of impressive really, and awkward and weird.

They have major ethical issues, discrimination issues, pay issues, leadership issues, training issues, collaboration issues... 

If you are looking for a job to make ends meet you are the employee they are looking for to pay you as little as possible and push you around until you give up or give in. If you are an critical thinker and respect yourself and others you may have a tough time.

As an admin in the department of surgery you will be in charge of patient relationships, all medical schedules, all appointment schedules and coordination, all patient communication, all interdepartmental communication, insurance auths, denials, appeals, managing surgical clinic and just about anything else that comes up . . . all for less than 20/hr. But whatever you do don’t ask for a raise — you’ll be told that “we all work hard” and it’s for a good cause: the patients. Patients and other medical staff will look at you as a lowly secretary. 

I held two positions and both times I was offered slightly higher pay than I was given (by 50 cents). This happened among all of the girls in the office. The average pay for my position was $60K. I made under $40K.

review_title: Wonderful People, lacks Professional Developing for non-Clinicians
pros: I have worked at BWH for about 2 and a half years now. I have been so blown away by the people I work with from clinical directors to security. Everyone seems to care deeply about what they do. My management staff has been wonderfully supportive of me while trying to help me grow and learn within the confines of their resources.
cons: Because this is a research/teaching hospital the vast majority of Professional Development opportunities (in the form of grants for education, mentoring, awards, etc) can only be applied for and awarded to clinicians. If you're in administration and would like to go to a conference or class there is little to no support, it's all out of pocket and the salaries aren't high enough to be able to afford additional out of pocket expenses. I can't even live in the city, I definitely can't afford to drop $1500 on a local conference.

review_title: Amazing opportunities, but capitalizes on "being BWH"
pros: Amazing opportunity to work with world-class doctors and other specialities and see what the level of care that a Harvard Teaching Hospital provides.  Awesome educational opportunities and great resume builder.
cons: Limited upward mobility in many departments.  Also, because it is a world-renowned hospital, the salaries tend to be lower than many other competitive hospitals.  Finally, the PTO or accrued time off is a huge problem for salaried employees.  BWH (and likely other Partners hospitals) lump together ALL your sick, vacation and holiday time.  There are no separate accrual banks for sick vs. vacation.  Therefore, you only have 29 "days off" per year, however you choose to use them.  If you subtract the 9 federal holidays, you're at 20 total days off per year.  While 4 weeks of "vacation" sounds good to some people, its only vacation if you're never sick and never need any personal time for appointments.  If you're really sick, then you're really screwed and on the flip side of that, the policy encourages people to come into work while feeling less than their best and puts others at risk.  This policy should really be reviewed by executive leadership within PHS.

job_title: RN Care Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: Great pay, good benefits, Union, good educational opportunities. Fair amount of atomomy in the job role.
cons:
As a Care Coordination RN I was told by a coworker that  I would probably learn 3 things pretty quickly to survive: 1. The dept. has extremely poor management so don'the expect much guidance. 2. Learn to fly below the radar .3. If you want a day off you have to call in sick because staffing is so short on a regular basis. These all proved to be true. By the time I left it was even worse as the Brigham has decided that when someone quits they will not be replaced. 
There's no set amount of patients per Care Coordinator and when someone is off you are often asked to cover their service along with your own. The managers do not have your back and the only time you hear from them is if there is a complaint or problem. Don't expect to be treated like a professional and do expect to fend for yourself on a daily basis. After a while the job becomes demoralizing.

review_title: Employees seem miserable and are very unfriendly. There's no sense of community
pros: My lab is fantastic and I have great colleagues who are friendly and helpful. The work that I do is very interesting and I'm learning a lot.
cons: I've only been an employee at BWH for 2 days but I can definitely tell that most employees don't seem happy. I've worked at two other nationally ranked hospitals in my career and there's a huge difference between those organizations and BWH regarding the overall atmosphere. All of the employees that I've interacted with so far seem uninterested in their work and are rude and cold. I greet people and they just ignore me and continue to assist me in a gruff manner. I volunteer at BIDMC and the people over there are much nicer and I feel like I'm a part of community when I'm there. On the bright side, I don't think I'll have to interact with too many people outside of my department. Also, the pay is really low. I realize this review might be a little premature since I'm still a new employee but I've never worked in a hospital where everyone is so unfriendly.

pros:
The union gets nursing some benefits
3 years gets you a pension, if you aren't tricked out of it by HR you can get an incredibly cheap heath insurance plan that is amazing, the scheduling is q 3rd weekend for anyone full time- which is only 40 hr employees- otherwise you could be working every other weekend depending on your manager. There is limited tuition reimbursement but they do give 1400 every two years for education.
cons: The union has the hospital at odds with nursing on many issues- things are contentious at the moment. They are cutting educators and making them management. They are frequently short staffed but just added many ftes. They pay is great but I'm doing this review so I can scan Glassdoor for more info on other loca hospitals because I want a pet diem option elsewhere as the work environment isn't always great.

review_title: Good place to start out, but not competitive enough to stay
pros: A big pro is job security. It is very hard to get fired at the Brigham because as a large company, it takes a long time to get things moving. That said, if you are on the right team they will hold you accountable. The Brigham mentality is also great, everyone here is very friendly and they seem to enjoy their jobs.
cons: Growth is very hard at the Brigham. There is a very hierarchical way of working here, and you need to be in charge of your own development within a position. Politics are everything, so if you network appropriately it'll be easier for you to move around. That said, they do love to hire from within so the experience is all about what you make of it.

pros: Speaking for research departments: talented people coming from great places all over the world; great health insurance benefits; flexible hours; quite many holidays.
cons: Very poor compensation in Harvard Medical School affiliated research labs. The salary offered to these greatly educated people, who are often at the cutting edge of biomedical sciences, is a cruel insult to their intelligence. Moreover, I have not seen genuine appreciation for the hard work people do. When bosses would offer something during so-called Friday "social hour", it's going to be the cheapest pizza one can buy and canned beer served somewhere in the corner of the hall room. As far as I have seen, the benefits are intentionally structured in the way to minimize chance that the employees would get anything; for example, to qualify for pension plan one would need to work three years but turnaround in research typically is just under that time.

pros: MNA Union, good benefits, good RN-patient staffing ratios. Great, dedicated rank-and-file doctors and nurses
cons: MNA union rules,  nursing seniority contributes to new RNs dissatisfaction, management incompetence (schedules and daily assignments  are mishandled multiple times). Hospital just got rid of all nursing educators last year. Poor MD staffing/coverage on off-shifts and holidays where one physician covers several units. There is high nursing turnover in some units due to low nurses satisfaction and poor support of nurses on the unit (No PCA on shifts, lack of equipment, delay in medications sent by pharmacy, lack of laundry, et).   Some of PCAs have the worst work ethic and pretty much useless. Some nursing supervisors have no clue what they are doing.

pros: Well respected and prestigious institution. Some of the best and cutting edge medical care and research is done here.
cons: The department I worked in was very unwelcoming to someone new to my particular role as far as training and staff support. From my second month there I felt like it was a burden to ask questions and was met with a culture of overall high expectation without the support to enable me to reach those expectations. My supervisor made her disapproval clear in the way I was treated and rather than empowering me to learn amongst my team-allowed my colleagues to run in her office and gossip. This was very much one of the worst job experiences I've ever encountered.

pros: You can put BWH on your resume. Honestly that's about it.
cons:
Every MD and Resident has their nose in the air and zero qualms about showing a lack of professionalism toward support staff. 

Most jobs (there are very few where I can say this) have a team based culture, but most is a "Whose To Blame."

Management is more likely to sweep problems under a rug or avoid the problem all together because of those MDs and Residents they cannot confront.

For lack of better words, if you like working thankless jobs and basically like being bumped into residents down hall ways who never apologize because they think they're better than you, you should def. work here.

job_title: Maintenance Mechanic and Electrical Qualified in Boston, MA
pros: Working at Brigham and Womens hospital has been a great experience, It is very competitive, pays well, and has been a great step stone for my next job offer
cons: As much as I appreciate what Brigham and womens hospital  has offered to me,  It Lacks good supervision, The hours are non -negotiable, we must work as many hours as needed including night, weekend and holiday's, which is hard to live and meet people when locked in room for as many hours as needed to you are relieved.

job_title: Patient Care Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Professional environment with high acuity makes for great learning and experience.  Perks such as employee picnics, swag and name recognition.  Great patients and meaningful work.
cons: It's so big that there is a lot of disenfranchisement, particularly in nurses, PCAs and environmental staff.  This leads to cutting corners and diminished of work culture.  Around patients, staff are generally great but with each other they can do less than their best and leave it for others.   It's unclear when supervisors will follow up or notice such behaviors -- at times they do so in a way that appears random and severe.  Most of the time it doesn't seem line anyone does anything.

review_title: A company that invests in its employees.
pros: The hospital is committed to encouraging its employees to take advantage of th multiple opportunities to further your education, whether it be through a conference,  a class, or higher degree.  Some college courses are even offerred at the hospital for convenience.  They are also big on formally recognizing the accomplishments of the staff, regardless of job title. Several times a year, calls for nominations are sent out to the employees to recognize our peers in various categories. Formal receptions are held to honor the recipients, once chosen.  I came to the Brigham from another area hospital and have never regretted my decision!
cons: I am very happy there and can't think of any right now.

review_title: Good hospital but variable by department
job_title: Research Lab Manager in Boston, MA
pros: Great benefits package. Centralized location in the Longwood area near Fenway. Well served by public transit. Hard working staff. Unique research opportunities.
cons: The working environment is highly variable based on department and direct supervisor. The group I entered had severely disgruntled and overworked staff where all but 1 planned to leave as soon as they found new employment. The head supervisor/manager knew just enough about managing a group of people to be dangerous. Being a content expert does not mean that you can run a research endeavor. Unfortunately the administrative oversight was poor, almost enabling the dysfunction. I would surmise that as long as the grant money is coming in, all other issues are ignored. Having been offered a leadership role and then being blocked from effecting any change, I left the organization.

pros:
Work life balance
Great benefits 
Well compensated
cons: Signs of union busting are everywhere. They're trying to reorganize to increase profits, but in doing so they are cutting corners and eliminating critical positions for optimal patient care i.e. Doing away with nurse educators, taking valuable PCA help from the floor to draw labs since they are eliminating phlebotomists completely in the fall, and they have grouped certain patient care areas together that are HORRIBLE heavy combinations with no education for nurses before these critical patients began showing up to the floor. Nurses are running ragged and morale is low.

review_title: Not all it is cracked up to be
pros: The pay and hours.  Opportunity to work with patients with complex diagnoses you don't see often in the communty setting.
cons:
Many negative/rude staff members.  I would never want to float to other units because there are A LOT of rude nurses also many of the assistants are rude and not helpful.  
Difficult working with multiple levels of doctors.  Communication is very poor among the medical teams & nurses directly caring for patients. 
A lot of young new nurses, feels safer to work with a mixed group with many experiences.  
Does not feel as patient-centered & family centered as a community hospital.
The union is a bit of pain, dues are expensive and the health benefits are not as good as the ones the hospital offers.

review_title: Highly competitive compensation; work satisfaction is largely dependent upon relationship with peers
pros: Excellent pay, excellent paid vacation options, highly reputable, excellent benefits,
cons: Once you get in it can be difficult to walk away from the hospital due to highly competitive financial compensation. If you dislike your department's culture. Communication disconnects between silos (especially nurse-pharmacy-physician groups). Management seeks feedback, but is largely powerless (due to current financial constraints) and often takes considerable time to enact change. Prioritization of problems is controlled from the top rather than determined by census through feedback. Some nurses (mostly senior) can take advantage of hardest working employees, but majority are team players.

pros:
Good benefits, first year is expensive for healthcare but goes down after that.
WFH flexibility.
cons: Terrible culture, you are constantly drowning in paper, tools and systems are very outdated, policies are all over the place, never enough admin support, 70+ jobs per person with so much paperwork that you never have a chance to even interview candidates. Gossipy environment that is left unchecked by leadership. Any process improvements or changes to the environment are strategically killed by departments that point fingers at each other for responsibility unto infinity until you just give up. Complain complain complain --no changes or proactive vision.  HR turnover is over 90% every two years- do not work here unless you want to push paper and lose sight of your career.

pros:
- salary is higher compared to other hospitals in Boston
- quality of services is generally great
- co-workers are all generally friendly
- shuttles to the hospital from locations throughout the city
cons:
- parking
- health benefits are really expensive for the 1st year you work at the hospital and then goes down (like 2x as much as other hospitals in the area for just employee)
- no team environment
- management is too busy (I have 3 supervisors for 1 job and they don't communicate and are definitely not on the same page ever)
- my position is new and it is extremely slow 
- if you are not a physician, you seem to be looked down upon by the physicians
- lack of training for positions
- lack of upward mobility

pros: BWH gives you the opportunity to show your skills and show them what your made of
cons: Doesn’t give applicants a FAIR chance to apply. If someone In house needs a spot, doesn’t matter whether they KNOW the position or not, they’ll take them First! Don’t feel it’s fair, an applicant MUST be screened on experience not convenience.

pros: BWH is a very well know institution and does amazing work. The hospital continues to push for innovation and is located in a great part of the city of Boston.
cons: It's difficult to leave a review of this nature since the positions vary so tremendously from one department to the next. However, within HR, there is quite the disconnect within the department and morale is lacking. There seems to be more concern with giving the department a superficial appearance of cohesiveness rather than paying attention to the actual needs of its employees.

pros: Amazing collaboration opportunities within the Longwood neighborhood. Access to cutting-edge facilities and cores. Decent variety of benefits and perks, which somewhat help with the poor pay.
cons: Compensation is very low, and the managerial bureaucracy is frustrating. HR seems overwhelmed and sometimes absentee; when notified of issues they seem more intent on hushing people up than resolving or preventing violations. Opportunities for growth or mentorship (in research) vary by PI, so there can be small groups with radically different internal norms from each other, which are sometimes at odds with stated BWH values or policy.

review_title: Good Benefits, Lots of Policies, Little Flexibility
pros: Good benefits with multiple options for healthcare depending on your needs and geographical location. Employees that want to make a difference - lots of well-educated and driven people! Opportunities for workplace development and education reimbursement. Awesome female CEO.
cons: Large org, so processes are complicated and bureaucratic. Processes change frequently without updated documentation. Lots of policies and restrictions that apply to employees even not working with patient care. Promotion can be challenging without leaving dept or employer. Less and less funding each year - leads to layoffs.

review_title: Great place to be an RN
pros:
Amazing benefits. Movement to different specialties/floors within the hospital. You see and learn so much on the job. Good staffing to patient ratios. Innovative environment always looking to enhance their practice and improve multidisciplinary teamwork.

Also, you work typical nursing hours and get paid overtime if you work more than 40 hours a week, leading to a great work/life balance.
cons: If you work on a med/surg floor, it is great experience, but can get exhausting. At times it seemed like you only care for drug addicts, nursing home patients who they need a break from, and patients who work the system and get admitted seeking pain medications. However, you can move to a calmer floor by internally applying.

job_title: Critical Care RN in Boston, MA
pros: I really feel supported by the MNA and could not be happier to have them as an active presence in the hospital. The critical care float pool manager is extremely helpful and fair. She makes great effort to support staff with their schedule requests, managing concerns and other comments. She is great with communication.
cons: The physician and other healthcare profession relationships are severely lacking. Constant push-pull dynamics in trying to provide the best care for patients. Lack of communication from physicians in terms of receiving orders on EMR. Could be a better working relationship for certain between nurses and doctors. This is not the case for all interactions but about 60% of interactions.

review_title: a fast paced place to work and learn
pros: Stimulating, academic, keeps you on your toes.  There is a lot of cutting edge reseach taking place, and lots of meetings and presentations on campus to keep yourself current and abreast of the research taking place.  There is tuition reimbursement so one can continue their education or pursue new avenues of learning to enhance their current job or pursue new positions.
cons: lack of employee parking, cumbersome communication at times because of size.  One of my pet-peeves is the amount of time it takes to get reimbursed from out-of-pocket expenses after taking mandatory trips.  More in-house training for entry level and mid-level positions would be appreciated.

pros: Great name brand hospital with name recognition.  Friendly employees.
cons: Management can be great or terrible depending on the department you work in.  Managers often pick their favorites.  There is little to no room for growth. The position has a very inflexible schedule with limited breaks.  30 min lunch must be taken however the two 15 minute breaks that you are supposed to get are often not taken because there is no coverage.

job_title: Access Facilatator/Bed Management in Boston, MA
pros: Has been a great place to work.   Allows for independent work styles.  Offers a good amount of time off.  They have also been great at getting extra help when an area is in need of more hands.
cons: difficult to get to.  I would not be able to handle the commute if it weren't for working weekends and then 2 off shift days during the week.    It is really hard to implement new systems.  Hospitals are feeling financially pinched and putting more and more pressure on their employes

review_title: Great experience working at this hospital
job_title: Hearing Screening Technician in Boston, MA
pros: I have been a per diem employee at BWH for almost 3 years, and I love the friendly work environment, as well as most of the employees and management I have personally worked with.  Great place to network and put on your resume as it is an amazing, cutting-edge hospital.
cons: Benefits are great -  unless you are not a full-time employee - small example, I used to be able to get a half-priced MBTA pass (which was very helpful in getting to work!) and non-exempt employees are no longer able to buy these. I personally have never had trouble, but I know that some people have had issues with management in the departments I work in.

pros: The hospital has a great mission statement and culture. Everyone is friendly, and because it is such a large institution, the benefits and support services are top notch.
cons: I have very few cons for working at the hospital. Perhaps the most would be salary. Although the hospital has a decent work to life balance, as a non-profit teaching hospital, the salary can be a little less than expected, but of course, this can also relate to position.

review_title: Top of the Field, Old-school Systems
pros: Lovely staff, with very caring coworkers. Very capable, intelligent dietitians who truly try to apply the most up-to-date knowledge/research to their practice. These folks are dedicated to the field of nutrition, and provide the upmost appropriate patient-centered care.
cons: Although the practice of the department is progressive, policies and procedures do not align with the expected application of practice.  There is some hierarchical issues that effect productivity and communication. The learning environment is ever-present, but navigating departmental dynamics can impede motivation and progress.

job_title: Director, Radiation Safety Officer in Boston, MA
pros: Leading-edge, ivy-league educated physicians, dedicated staff. Hospital searches to implement new techniques and procedures in medical care. Good Teaching Hospital.  Hospital very close to a T train stop. Free shuttle service to & from other Partners locations, which is how I commuted into work.
cons: Very Limited parking. Typical Teaching Hospital problems.  Very political environment in administration.  Insecure management due to politics. Medical Directors can be fiercely protective of their turf; sometimes leading to too many cooks (or specialists) in the kitchen, especially among joint ventures or new technologies that are shared by specialties or fields.  Research end is totally grant dependent for funds.

job_title: Technical Research Assistant II in Boston, MA
pros: Located in Boston, you'll make plenty of connections with Beth Israel, Children's, Dana Farber, HMS, etc. all within walking distance. Plenty of opportunity for collaboration. BWH is a top hospital with top doctors and researchers. The hospital also has perks such as discounted tickets to museums, aquariums, six flags, and even sox games.
cons: Boston can be expensive to live in/near. Expect to pay $1400+ just in rent per month to live alone, plus amenities, and in my case my pay at the institution was barely enough to break even each month. Commuting into the city is extremely difficult and parking will cost you money, and as far as I know BWH did not have any reimbursement policy.

review_title: Good name, good benefits but your work experience will be dependent on your boss.
pros: The benefits are good and there is great name recognition. If you work in the right division, you can reap the rewards of talented colleagues and dedicated support staff.
cons: Working at a HMS affiliated hospital means that you have to deal with some pretty arrogant doctors; the red tape can get frustrating if you work in administration; and so much of your daily quality of life depends on your relationship with your supervisor. Get a good manager/lab supervisor/project leader, and it can be great; get a bad one, and you'll be on your own.

pros:
- salary is higher compared to other hospitals in Boston
- shuttles to the hospital from locations throughout the city
- good benefits
cons:
- health insurance is expensive for the 1st year then decreases after 1 year
- the TBSCC is extremely disorganized and poorly run - new management is needed; management is condescending, egotistical, & rude; there is very low morale in the department; lots of turnover recently
- non clinical staff often have very little work to do, so they sit around texting/on the internet all day while clinical staff are running around crazy busy

pros: Great perks for all employees, excellent health benefits. Relaxed and friendly work environment (that I have found) and a well known hospital in Boston.
cons:
Bureaucratic to some extent, a lot of administration staff, some admins are required and do excellent jobs but some make a big deal out of their menial responsibilities and ultimately hinder work flow.

Career advancement in the research end of BWH isn't really anything outside of being paid more and given more responsibilities. There aren't really "ranks" outside of Professor, Instructor, Researcher... the former two of which are life long goals for some.

pros: BWH is always trying to move forward with diversity and cooperation and hires to the strengths of their workers backgrounds and interests. Best boss of my life works here, and she challenges and encourages me to showcase my worth. I feel valued as an employee, who is also queer and female.
cons: There can be a lot of disorganization from department to department, and it takes a while to be trained on protocols. Once aware of who knows what, it is fine.

review_title: Great place to start to professional field. Foot in the door
pros: Not awful right away, somewhere to start something to have your foot in the door for countless opportunities by getting to know the community. Gain plenty of knowledge but know most after about 6 months.
cons: This department itself, treat you like you should know everything, not apologetic when they are wrong, assigns you literally so many roles that its countless and if lack knowledge they dont train you in, they will give you a lecture how you should catch on.

review_title: It all depends on your PI...
pros: When getting bonus at the end of year, the basic research staff was included - even postdocs! (Which in my experience is something very rare...)
cons: The same old sad story - you are required to work overtime which you won't get paid for and pay is rather small. Since dependent on funding, make sure that when boss tells you he/she has money for you for xy years, that he really got grants to back his/her words with.

job_title: Research Technician II in Boston, MA
pros:
Lots of paid vacation. Easy access by public transit. There are many opportunities to expose oneself to the latest research in your field of interest. 

Use any time spent in an academic setting to absorb as many skills as possible. Gain proficiency in assays and develop new skills.
cons:
BWH relies heavily on scientists and academics to perform as managers. Although a PhD may qualify someone as an expert in their field of interest, it does not equip them with the necessary tools to manage a lab, personnel, or resources efficiently. 

This employee was very dissatisfied with the lack of organization and repeated hiring blunders of their manager.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Boston, MA
pros: MNA,  competitative rates, many specialities to choose from.  Many nurses have been working at the Brigham since they began their career.  That speaks volumes !
cons: tough place to get an RN job sometimes...people just don't leave.  Sometimes new RN's are overwhelmed...very sick patients.   No parking on site unless you work nights....so you either have to take the T or park on an off site lot and get shuttled in.  Depending upon what shift you work and traffic this can add extra time to your commute.

review_title: Was expecting better parental leave policies
pros: Great location, great reputation.  Brigham and Women's Hospital is a very well-known and prestigious hospital.  They also have a good benefits package (with the exception of maternity leave, for which I was expecting a bit more)
cons: For an employer with the word "Women's" in the name, I really expected them to have a better system in place for maternity and paternity leave.  I'm disappointed.

There's a superficial commitment to "diversity" and "bias" training. There's a serious lack of Black and other POC representation (nearly nonexistent), especially in leadership.  Once you get to know the inside drama, it becomes apparent that there are lots of problems because of pettiness and a hyper-hierarchical environment.

pros: They have excellent benefits and employee perks such as discounted movie tickets and lift tickets and the yearly employee appreciation celebration is one of the best at a company I have attended. It is also pretty easy to transfer jobs once you are a part of the Brigham which i believe helps to retain good employees.
cons: Pay scales are fairly rigid and do not allow for flexibility to take into account experience and education, "everything must be equitable". Also due to an unfortunate incident with time reporting, these rules have become extremely strict.

pros: The opportunities available are great; seminars, workshops, etc. Being in the Longwood Area increases exposure and networking. The research is solid and many labs are well-funded.
cons: The hospital has so many policies in place with no way to implement them. Faculty can easily take advantage of their postdocs. Many labs don't care about the development of their postdocs with PI's giving bad recommendations after working there for 10 years.

pros: Resources and mentorship abound in the research arena - the place is clearly a primarily research focused institute with a patient care mission which is also extremely strong - The overall experience is very much driven by the individual department within which one finds themselves, but globally a very positive place.
cons: Seems to have less brand-recognition than other equal hospital centers both within Boston/New England and nationally - clearly one of the ten best hospitals in the country but lesser known to many outsiders.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Norwood, MA
pros: The company offers excellent benefits and a wide range of career opportunities. They also work with College for America to offer employees the chance to receive a degree in business or healthcare administration at zero cost. Support staff are viewed as potential future leaders and management encourages upward career movement amongst staff.
cons: I work in a satellite primary care office, so having to visit the main BWH campus in Boston for training is very cumbersome. Boston traffic is unpredictable and parking is costly.

pros: Amazing learning opportunity for those interested in medicine. Location is in the hub of medicine in Boston. People are willing to teach if you mention and remind them that you want to learn. Great medical benefits. Decent pay.
cons: Administration tends to think that because this is BWH, you are lucky to even be there. I have had multiple instances of this in multiple clinics. Having so many students/residents can cut into learning time for those outside of these fields.

review_title: Great People, but management is out of touch
pros: Great perks for all employees
cons: Unionized nurses are the primary,if not only, focus for managment when making decisions that affect all employees.  No consideration for per diem employees.

review_title: A good working environment with great people.
pros: I really enjoy working at Brigham and Women's Hospital because of the people around me. My research team is helpful and there is a very collaborative attitude about our work.
cons: One of the downsides of Brigham and Women's Hospital is that it is an exceptionally large institution. It is not difficult to get caught up in some of the institutional bureaucracy. The check issuing system for reimbursements for travel expenses takes WAY too long.

pros: They love to promote within, systems are nice and new and easy to use, Job stability.
cons: Pay can be a bit low, forces people to move around within the organization a lot.

review_title: Interesting Place to Work with Smart People -- Where Quality and Safety Matters.
pros: People are here to provide the best care possible for patients, advance science, and train the next generation of care providers.  People are mission-driven.  People do care about safety and quality.  The hospital has the resources to invest in technologies and people to make this place better.  It is expanding and growing.  Not too political or old fashioned.  Many smart people with great ideas.  As this is a teaching hospital, people are willing to teach.  The overall culture is collaborative and stimulating.  A great place to learn as much as one can and advance as much as one can.   Talents are recognized.  Also, it's nice to work for a well-known and respected institution.
cons: Nursing union where there's not enough accountability and ownership.  Too much "that's my job" attitude for the amount of money they are paid.  That said, the nurses here are good to the patients.  Turf wars between specialties, though that is common in other hospitals as well.  Some of the people here have been here forever, so they are stuck in their old ways.  There's a new crop of managers with MBAs and MPHs so they bring an element of business discipline to this craft.  That balances nicely with those who have been here for a while and are politically savvy.  The pay isn't competitive but I am told that the benefit package is generous.  The hours can be long simply because those whom we serve (physicians) are workhorses.  Some meetings are held 6 or 7am in the morning or 6pm in the evening.  They meetings are interesting but difficult to juggle for those with little kids.

pros: High-expectations, top-notch patient-centered care, facilitates growth/learning because it is a teaching hospital. Turn-over rate is high in some departments, but if you want to stay here for a long-term period, you will have no problem keeping your job.
cons: Difficult to make changes in policies/regulations and difficult to reach upper management, Partners is going through a budget crunch so raises are given annually but they are minimal. Parking is a very difficult task for employees and it is unfortunate that people commute from all over the state to work at this prime institution and do not have proper parking access.

review_title: I love working here at BWH.
job_title: Research Assistant II in Boston, MA
pros: I love the team I work with, and I think the benefits we get are awesome. I never run out of PTO. The Brigham is a great institution, and it is pretty cool to think about all the great minds you're surrounded by here.
cons: The pay for the position I'm in is not so competitive (when you compare to other cities), but I think that's just because everyone wants to work in the Harvard and Partners systems. Also, some of the administrative hoops you have to jump through to get your work done can be frustrating.

review_title: Never let an employer show you twice that they undervalue you
pros: Laboratory was well funded. Good discounts on Ski passes and movie tickets. Cafeteria breakfast and pizza was always good.
cons: Poor annual review practices. 2% annual raise for each employee regardless of performance quality. Promotions earn you a 5% raise. Gets especially frustrating when you take into consideration that annual inflation for 2018 and 2019 are 1.7% and 1.8% respectively.

review_title: Great opportunity to expand skill set, but management treats employees poorly
job_title: Technical Research Assistant II in Boston, MA
pros:
Great laboratory work environment
Excellent Health Care Benefits
Perfect environment to expand skill set and work with collaborators
Plenty of opportunities for attending conferences and acquiring CEUs
Centrally located
cons:
Complete lack of communication from management to employers
No sense of urgency from management
Poor pay and commute/parking compensation 
Difficult to achieve promotions
Poor attention to detail from management
Poorly written HR documents

pros: Health insurance benefit is very good. Some very good PIs here doing interesting things.
cons: Time off and retirement not so good compared with the rest of Harvard.  Treats all workers as if the work with patients.  Bureaucratic at times.  Salary is low for Boston.  Easy to get lost.  A lot depends on your boss.

pros: I was a patient at Brigham and Women's Hospital for a long time. In 2004, I had a difficult pregnancy. The staff at the hospital helped me go through it. I saw how much they care about the people. That is the reason why I will like to work over there. I want to learn how to help people just as the way I was helped.
cons: I really do not know what I don't like because it is a good place.

pros:
Big hospital, great research facilities, intensive and interactive research.
Good health insurance.
Despite all cons in below, you can meet really good, honest and smart people.
cons:
Career growth for PhD scientists is very challenging. it highly depends on your PI and division chief policy. There is no pipeline of career growth for PhDs. 
Overall, hospital is targeted to breed physician-scientists (people with eligible MD to practice in US). 
Salary for postdocs is in average lower than proposed by NIH standards but again depends on PI. this is a big issue, BWH does not force PIs to pay on NIH standards, PIs basically decide how much they want to pay you. It is funny because 99% of PIs get their funds from NIH.
There is no institutional support for green card application for foreigners, if you are not faculty (postdoc is not faculty), BWH does not write a petition letter thus you can't apply as EB1 category, which is quite critical for people from India and China. Initially, you get J1 and later can switch to H1B, but switch to H1B is totally depends on your PI. In my case, division pays nothing regarding to processing fees etc, my PI signed his own paycheck and this is not usual, usually PI does not want to pay from their own pocket, thus you need to pay for everything, which is quite ridiculous because H1B is employment based working visa. But again this is what I've experienced, maybe in other divisions different way of doing things.
NO retirement plans for postdocs. 
Overall, BWH does not give anything for postdocs (PhDs), it is like they throw you in the middle of river and you either learn how to swim or sink.

review_title: It is challenging and exciting, but well-suited by people who don't need any support of any kind.
pros: It is an exciting place to be, very cutting-edge and world-renowned. The salary and compensation packages are good. Boston is a nice place to live.
cons: It is unsupportive for junior faculty, and the environment is so big that it is challenging to navigate. There's not much in the way of mentorship.

review_title: This is a great place to start an entry level position
job_title: Clinical Research Associate in Quincy, MA
pros: BWH is a great place to start off in an entry level position.  The benefits are excellent.  Health/dental insurance is inexpensive and very good.  Paid time off is also great.  There are a lot of opportunities to learn and gain experience in order to move onto something else.
cons: While the benefits are excellent, the pay is a little low.  There aren't a lot of opportunities to move up.  The company seems to overlook certain problems, such as poor management.

review_title: PI can cap your salary and no increases for number of years
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Boston, MA
pros: Good to be in a place where you have all the facility and money to do research.
cons: Hospital has a policy where individual PI can freeze postdoc salary for number of years. It is a shame to work like crazy and do not get paid well or increase every year to keep up with inflation.

review_title: Exceptional doctors and respect for patients
job_title: New Patient Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: I enjoyed my time here - and learned so much in my time here. You can tell BWH is a leader among the other hospitals in the region. Good benefits - the work will depend on what department you're in.
cons: BWH has a lot of respect for having some of the best doctors - but expect the patients to expect immediate and extreme care. Management is doing their best to be a liaison between docs and admins but its a battle not done yet.

review_title: Great for starting but not long term.
job_title: Research Assistant II in Boston, MA
pros: Working environment here is great. Lots of ways to stay connected in research and clinical. People all around are kind and helpful and there is always something going on. Center for a lot of cutting edge research and also linked with Harvard University. It's a great place to work right out of school to get some experience and big names on your resume.
cons: There isn't much room for salary growth, annual increases of 1-2%. It is also takes a long time to reach a new level.

review_title: Pay PMs for their hard work and continued service.
job_title: Research Project Manager in Boston, MA
pros: You work with the best doctors and researchers in the country. There is lots of research conducted here so it's possible to find another study to work on if your grant runs out.
cons: Salary not competitive at all compared to industry/technology. PMs highly undervalued. No stabdardized procedures, resources or professional development for PMs. No group that leads/coordinates PMs across large divisions or across the Institution.

review_title: Dysfunctional Nightmare on every level the HR dept.
pros: I cannot find any pro's in this dept. Toxic, treacherous, not healthy.
cons: Think of the Trump administration? You have all these Business Partners that can't even pass the SHRM course- test provided? They are awful and so negative. There turnover is immense, you would think it is a place to grow? No way, it's very political and if you don't do your job you will be in that inner toxic circle, if you do your job, you will not fit in..

pros: Front line level physicians are hard working and dedicated.  A lot of training is available and benefits are pretty good.  There are many opportunities to work with highly skilled professionals and leaders in their field.  Pay is slightly better than average.

pros: The benefits package for health care (including vision and dental). The hospital name is a resume booster. Access to Harvard Medical School resources.
cons: There is poor management by administration and there is a huge disconnect between the very high up administration and CEO's sense of reality and what is taking place on the ground. Policies fail and employees suffer and leave due to this.

review_title: No Care, No Coordination Part II
pros: Brigham and Women's is a great hospital. Amazing things are happening here and seeing it first hand is a really cool experience. Great resume builder.
cons: The Care Coordination department is probably one of the worst to work for at the Brigham. The head honchos know very little about what goes on, on a daily basis. They know nothing about what the Resource Specialist role or what we can and cannot do. We are told by management that we are an asset to the "team" but are, 100% of the time, ignored when we have questions or suggestions to improve quality of work. When something goes wrong, no matter the fault, the finger is always pointed back at the Resource Specialist. Many CCRNs are great at their and hard working individuals. Others are very rude, immature and manipulative. Medical team staff has complained to management about certain CCRNs and even and requested they be removed from their service team. Management has ignored these multiple requests due to the CCRNs being "stressed". Giving the CCRNs an excuse for this behavior makes it even worse. Often times, these are the CCRNs who are a part of every committee representing Care Coordination, which is an embarrassment. Resource Specialists never receive replies about topics, ie: vacation requests, meeting requests, simple questions. The lack of organization, knowledge, and respect make this a difficult department to work for. Many things need to change in order to make it worth staying for 2-3 years. We are very underpaid for the work we do. As college graduates, mostly in debt, there needs to be a higher minimum salary. Management expects Resource Specialists to stay for life when we are treated terribly and not paid enough in, essentially, a dead end job.

pros: The number of quality labs and resources increases the possibility of doing impactful and interesting science.  A good training environment with lots of agencies and personnel to help post-doctoral fellows like myself in their career.

pros: BWH is an overall great company to work for. There are many opportunities for advancement within the partners community once you get your foot in the door. Working for BWH is a great resume builder, and it really means something to the world when you say you've worked here.

Rs in particular are treated with no respect. They treat you as an incompetent worker just because RS are more of a younger crowd, they treat you as though you have no education or work experience. You are treated as if you are not qualified to do the job. They talk to you in threatening and a demeaning manner, such as getting in the face of employees. Rs are more than capable of handling their job description. Let's not forget at any given moment management and other colleagues change your job role. They are very sneaky in trying to change minor descriptions and hoping the team won’t notice and without alerting HR. It’s no wonder that this job has a high turnover rate.

review_title: Make this a temporary position at best
pros:

cons:

* Toxic environment

There are so many cons I had to list them and then discuss them in detail. First things first, you will have little to no training and be left to figure out how your department works on your own. Most of the providers here do not care for administrative staff and can be downright nasty.  You will often have things that go wrong blamed on you if I can be blamed and you will often be criticized for things that would never come up. 

Days drag on, random people will come up to you and ask you for things that are so far removed from your job description, you will start to question your own existence. Upper management will only pay attention to you if they receive blowback, otherwise no one will even know you exist in the first place. On top of that, because of the lack of management, organization, and respect, other support staff are openly toxic, vindictive, and untrustworthy. This is a medical office that feels more like a car dealership. If you're desperate and in serious need of getting some quick money, then you'll be hired in no time. But do not plan on sticking here longer than even 8 months. You'll lose your sanity, you'll be constantly disrespected, underpaid, and criticized for all of your "mistakes" and all of the things that you do well will be ignored.

review_title: Management and Care Providers are at direct odds with one another
pros: I loved the direct team of MAs I worked with, as well as the physicians and PAs. The position I was in was designed for college-educated non-certified MAs to gain clinical hours and experience to then apply to PA/Med school.
cons: There was a substantial amount of Epic/computer training, but very little instruction on how to perform the actual job. Additionally, as most hospitals are, many of the admins perform low-quality work and repeatedly make the same mistakes, that we are then forced to pick up the slack for. There were never any consequences to anyone in administrative roles, and they are impossible to fire, which leads to a glut of unqualified and poor workers, which then hinder every other aspect of hospital operations. My team was micro-managed, and yet when we did have problems, such as direct conflict between what two different doctors wanted (ex, both wanted access to the ultrasound at the same time) we were told to "figure it out". The idea that the lowest people on the totem pole (MAs) would "tell doctors what to do" is ridiculous and insulting. Also, the hospital was greedy. It seems silly, but for all the time we worked there, we never even got so much as a t-shirt. We were expected to PAY for merchandise with the hospital's logo on it. They told us "we should be grateful" when we were given a half-eaten platter of cold sandwiches after we were forced to work through lunch due to short staffing. Additionally, management bullied us, making comments on our appearances/weight, literally workplace harassment. When one of us left the company, even if we gave 6+ weeks notice, they never started looking for a replacement until after the employee had left, leaving us all short-staffed, unable to use vacation time for months at a time. When a new employee was not capable of performing the work, even after months of training, we expressed that to management. We were yelled at and told "it's your fault he's not getting it, you're not training him properly!!" even though every other employee my team had trained has understood and subsequently been able to perform their job. The patients were rude, and instead of the doctors having an ounce of backbone and telling them "no, we can't see you when you show up two hours late and yell at the receptionists" they let them in, where we are then expected to accommodate their poor behavior. All in all, I was miserable from start to finish during my time at BWH, and I'm so relieved to have left. I will never go back there, not even for my own care. After seeing what goes on behind the scenes, I don't trust any of the less-qualified MAs or Admins.

pros: Overall had a great experience with the people and the position.  Great facilities to work in, and management was great.
